title: 104_hr1406
content: The Act is titled the "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" and outlines specifications for the commemorative coin. The "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $1 silver coins and half dollar clad coins in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan and George Catlett Marshall. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The half dollar coins will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to specific specifications. The coins minted under the "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" are legal tender and considered numismatic items under the United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan and feature George C. Marshall. The coins will also include inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "1997", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins minted under this Act shall be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the George C. Marshall Foundation, Friends of George C. Marshall, and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 1997, with minting authority ending on December 31, 1997. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges of $12 per coin for the $1 coin will be included in all sales. The $1 coin will be sold at $12 per coin, and the half dollar coin will be sold at $4 per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales under this Act will be divided equally between the George C. Marshall Foundation for educational programs and the Friends of George C. Marshall for the construction of a memorial center. The Comptroller General can audit the Foundation and Friends for expenditure oversight. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a depository institution is in place.
